text: God hath spoken once; twice have I heard this; that power belongeth unto God.
text_kjv: God hath spoken once; twice have I heard this; that power belongeth unto God.
text_niv: One thing God has spoken,two things have I heard:that you, O God, are strong,
text_esv: Once God has spoken; twice have I heard this: that power belongs to God,
text_nlt: God has spoken plainly,and I have heard it many times:Power, O God, belongs to you;
text_msg: God said this once and for all;how many timesHave I heard it repeated?"Strength comesStraight from God."
text_nasb: Once God has spoken; Twice I have heard this: That power belongs to God;
context: Psalm 62 is attributed to David, likely written during a period of turmoil and threat from his enemies, possibly during Absalom's rebellion. Understanding the historical context helps us grasp the psalm's focus on trust in God as a refuge. The 'power' referenced in verse 11 isn't simply brute strength, but rather the sovereign authority and capacity to act decisively and justly. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, power was often associated with deities, kings, and military might. Kings derived their authority, at least nominally, from divine endorsement. However, David, rather than looking to alliances with other nations or relying solely on his own military prowess, acknowledges that ultimate power and security reside in God alone. The repetition, 'God hath spoken once; twice have I heard this,' highlights the importance of heeding God's word. In a society where oracles and divine pronouncements were considered significant, the doubling emphasizes the certainty and reliability of the message. This wasn't a single, isolated revelation but a consistent truth revealed repeatedly, perhaps through different experiences or prophetic words. David lived in a world where stability was precarious, and political machinations were rife. This instability makes his declaration of God's power and trustworthiness all the more potent. It underscores a deliberate choice to ground his hope not in fleeting human strength, but in the eternal and unwavering power of God.
meaning: The theological meaning of Psalm 62:11 centers on the nature of God's power and its implications for human trust and security. The statement 'God hath spoken once; twice have I heard this' doesn't necessarily denote two separate pronouncements. Instead, it signifies an emphatic confirmation of a fundamental truth. The repetition underscores the sureness and reliability of God's power; it is not a fleeting or uncertain attribute. The core theological idea is that all power ultimately belongs to God. This is not merely physical strength but also moral authority, sovereign control, and the capacity to bring about His will. God's power is not arbitrary or capricious; it is exercised in accordance with His character, which is just, merciful, and loving. Recognizing God's absolute power has profound implications. It means that human power, whether political, economic, or personal, is finite and ultimately subordinate to God's sovereignty. This realization should lead to humility and a rejection of self-reliance. The psalmist, in acknowledging God's power, implicitly acknowledges his own dependence on God. The verse also speaks to God's self-sufficiency. He does not derive power from any external source; it is intrinsic to His being. This contrasts sharply with earthly rulers, whose power is often contingent upon the consent of the governed, military strength, or economic resources. Understanding this truth empowers believers to face adversity with courage and hope. Because God possesses all power, He is able to protect, provide for, and ultimately deliver those who trust in Him. This verse refutes the notion that evil forces or worldly powers are ultimately victorious. God remains sovereign, and His power will ultimately prevail.
application: In modern life, Psalm 62:11 serves as a powerful reminder to ground our hope and security in God, not in the transient and unreliable things of this world. We live in a culture that often equates power with wealth, influence, or social status. This verse challenges us to re-evaluate our understanding of power and to recognize that true power resides in God alone. Practically, this means turning to God in prayer and seeking His guidance in all aspects of our lives. It means trusting in His provision and protection, even when circumstances seem bleak. We can apply this verse by actively resisting the temptation to rely on our own strength or abilities. This may involve surrendering control of a situation to God, acknowledging our limitations, and seeking His help. The repetition in the verse encourages us to regularly meditate on God's power and sovereignty. This could involve studying scripture, spending time in prayer, or reflecting on past experiences where we witnessed God's power at work. Recognizing God's power can also transform our relationships with others. Instead of seeking to control or manipulate others, we can treat them with compassion and respect, recognizing that they, too, are ultimately subject to God's authority. Furthermore, this verse calls us to be discerning about where we place our trust. We should be wary of ideologies, movements, or leaders that promise salvation or security apart from God. Instead, we should test everything against the standard of God's word and seek His wisdom in all matters. In times of crisis or uncertainty, Psalm 62:11 serves as an anchor, reminding us that God is in control and that His power is sufficient to meet all our needs. It is a call to faith, perseverance, and unwavering trust in the one who holds all power in His hands. Ultimately, embracing this truth allows us to live with greater peace, confidence, and purpose, knowing that our lives are secure in the hands of a loving and all-powerful God.
prayer: Almighty God, sovereign Lord, I come before you acknowledging that all power belongs to you. Forgive me for the times I've placed my trust in fleeting things, in my own strength, or in the promises of the world. Your word has spoken, and I have heard it, again and again â€“ your power is unmatched, your reign is eternal. Help me to truly grasp the depth of your authority, to rest in your provision, and to lean on your unwavering strength. Grant me the grace to release my anxieties and fears, knowing that you are fully in control. Fill me with your peace that surpasses all understanding. May my life be a testament to your power and love, a beacon of hope in a world that desperately needs to know you. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The repetition emphasizes the certainty and reliability of God's message. It's not a singular, possibly unreliable, event but a confirmed truth. This stresses the importance of paying attention to God's established word and character.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why is the repetition 'God has spoken once; twice have I heard this' important?

faqs.answer: Knowing God's power reminds you that He is sovereign and in control, even when things seem chaotic. This trust alleviates fear because you are not solely responsible for the outcome; God is guiding you.
faqs.question: Q2: How does understanding God's power help me overcome fear in difficult times?

faqs.answer: It means that ultimate authority and capacity reside in God. Humans have delegated power, but it's always subordinate to and derived from God's sovereignty. He's the source of all power.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean to say that power 'belongeth unto God'? Does it mean humans have no power?

faqs.answer: Regularly meditate on God's power through scripture and prayer. Consciously choose to trust God's provision instead of relying solely on your abilities and resources, surrendering control to Him.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I practically apply Psalm 62:11 in my daily life?

faqs.answer: No, it means striving within the context of God's will and trusting in His guidance. Pursue goals ethically and diligently, but recognize that ultimate success depends on God's blessing and timing.
faqs.question: Q5: Does acknowledging God's power mean I shouldn't strive for success or achieve my goals?
